newsitem.title: FRANCE: French stocks finish slightly lower.
newsitem.headline: French stocks finish slightly lower.

text.p: French stocks snapped a three-session winning streak on Monday after investors took profits on news of a long-awaited compromise deal by European Union leaders to keep the single currency project on track.

The market rose to all-time highs early on Monday on expectations that EU leaders meeting in Amsterdam would reach a compromise agreement to enforce budget discipline in the single European currency zone and strive to create more jobs.
Brokers said the bourse was shifting its focus to Prime Minister Lionel Jospin's keynote policy address on June 19.
The CAC-40 index closed down 12.65 points, or 0.45 percent, at 2,795.87 after easing from an all time high at 2,825.18.
Volume was 6.7 billion francs, relatively modest as many investors held to the sidelines ahead of the Amsterdam summit declaration.
After three sessions of gains and a rise early on Monday to an all time high of 2,825.18 points, the bourse was due for a consolidation, traders said.
In addition to the political and monetary developments in Europe, investors are waiting for U.S. consumer price, capacity utilisation and industrial production data on Tuesday.
One broker noted the bourse has become expensive, with a Price-Earnings ratio of 27, surpassed in Europe only by Germany, Switzerland and Hungary.
